I am a PhD student in Ecology and Environmental Sciences at Montana State University, where I specialize in the biological control of invasive plant species. My research focuses on leveraging insect agents to manage yellow and Dalmatian toadflax in Montana and South Dakota, aiming to provide sustainable solutions for invasive species management and ecosystem restoration.
I live in Bozeman with my wife Grace where we enjoy running, biking, and skiing.


 MS Entomology - Montana State University
 BS Biology - University of Minnesota

title: Jackson Strand
text:
About me
I am currently a PhD candidate at Montana State University studying entomology. I live in Bozeman, MT with my wife Grace.
My Research Interests
I am broadly interested in how insects impact the lives of humans and how we can better utilize them to positively impact modern issues such as crop yield, climate change, and waste management.
Montana State University - MS Entomology
My research focused on understanding how the ecological relationship between the wheat stem sawfly (Cephus cinctus) and two native biocontrol parasitoids (Bracon cephi and Bracon lissogaster) are impacted by smooth brome (Bromis inermis). My project includes field sites in southwest, central, and northern Montana, as well as volatile organic compound analysis of greenhouse-grown smooth brome and winter wheat.




  
  
  Image Gallery

title: Jackson R. Strand
text:
Research Experience



Montana State University


2021-Present




Understanding ecological importance of smooth brome (Bromus inermis) in biological control of wheat stem sawfly (Cephus cinctus) using native braconid parasitoids.

Field work collecting smooth brome and winter wheat samples from southwest, central, and northern Montana.
Controlled wheat stem safwly infestation of smooth brome using insect netting and PVC cages.
Collection of volatile organic compounds (VOCs) using greenhouse volatile collection system.
Gas chromatography - mass spectroscopy (GCMS) run on VOC samples, data processed and analyzed using RStudio.
Electroantennogram - Flame Ionization Detector (EAD-FID) run on parasitoids to measure response to smooth brome and winter wheat VOCs.

Locoweed

Collected VOCs from greenhouse and field Oxytropis sericea specimens using greenhouse volatile collection system and push-pull field volatile collection system.
GCMS run on VOC samples, data processed and analyzed using RStudio.

Biocontrol of Salt Cedar (Tamarix ramosissima) using subtropical tamarisk beetle (Diorhabda sublineata) in eastern Montana.

Field work setting up insect cages on large salt cedar plants in central Montana.
Collected salt cedar plants using pulaski from south central Montana.

title: Jackson R. Strand
text:
Research Interests
I am broadly interested in understanding the ecological roles of insects and their potential to address pressing global challenges, including improving agricultural productivity, combating climate change, and advancing waste management strategies. Through my research, I seek to develop innovative, nature-based solutions to these complex problems, focusing on the intersection of entomology, ecology, and sustainability.
My master‚Äôs thesis with Dr.¬†David Weaver focused on the agroecological role of smooth brome grass in managing wheat stem sawfly (WSS) populations. Specifically, I investigated how smooth brome could serve as a trap crop to reduce WSS larvae and provide a refuge for parasitoids like Bracon cephi and B. lissogaster. Using a combination of volatile organic compound (VOC) analysis and field observations, I demonstrated that smooth brome, when grown adjacent to wheat fields, could reduce WSS survival and support second-generation parasitoids. Please see my thesis defense for more detailed findings.





  
  
  Image Gallery
  




  
  
  
  
  
  


  










  You can view my CV contents below, or download my CV here:

Pace Analytical- Onsite at 3M ‚Äì Regulatory IT Analyst (Maplewood, MN) 2013-2017 2017-2021 ‚Ä¢ Provided digital support between 3M employees and the 3M Chemical Data Management System (CDMS). ‚Ä¢ Integrated, tested, and supported user and data interface between CDMS and SAP. ‚Ä¢ Generated, designed, and communicated unique, detailed reports of material information using SQL, Microsoft Excel, and SAP.

title: Jackson Strand
text:
The Land Resources and Environmental Science (LRES) Graduate Student Organization (GSO) is a student-run group at Montana State University, working to provide community, workshops, and social and professional networking opportunities for grad students in the department. LRES boasts a wide range of diversity, from plant scientists, to environmental microbiologists, to hydrologists, and the GSO exists to help students take advantage of the rich knowledge base that this broad range of interests encompasses.
LRES GSO 2024 LRES-PSPP Student Research Symposium

Concious Spending Plan
A guide to creating a personal financial plan that prioritizes essential spending and savings. It is a useful resource for developing a budget that reflects your personal financial goals.

title: Jackson R. Strand
text:
Research Interests zzzzz
I am broadly interested in understanding the ecological roles of insects and their potential to address pressing global challenges, including improving agricultural productivity, combating climate change, and advancing waste management strategies. Through my research, I seek to develop innovative, nature-based solutions to these complex problems, focusing on the intersection of entomology, ecology, and sustainability.
My master‚Äôs thesis with Dr.¬†David Weaver focused on the agroecological role of smooth brome grass in managing wheat stem sawfly (WSS) populations. Specifically, I investigated how smooth brome could serve as a trap crop to reduce WSS larvae and provide a refuge for parasitoids like Bracon cephi and B. lissogaster. Using a combination of volatile organic compound (VOC) analysis and field observations, I demonstrated that smooth brome, when grown adjacent to wheat fields, could reduce WSS survival and support second-generation parasitoids. Please see my thesis defense for more detailed findings.


  You can view my CV contents below, or download my CV here:
  
    View my CV
